Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Sustainable material use in laser deposition: integrating experimental design, environmental impact assessment and economic evaluation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605392
Schoebubg, Julie M.

Conventional methods used to fabricate metallic components generally require casting or wrought fabrication processes such as extrusion or forging. Secondary machining steps are generally necessary in order to achieve specified surface finish, dimensional accuracy and geometrical complexity. But machining wastes both material, i.e., the scrap material removed from the bulk part (machining chips), and energy, rendering conventional methods highly inefficient from a sustainability perspective. As an alternative, direct metal deposition techniques are being explored, which create solid metal parts by melting metal powder and depositing material only where it is wanted, thus fabricating the component by adding, rather than subtracting material. This change in fabrication strategy is intended to inherently reduce both energy requirements and material waste by avoiding (or reducing) the extent of secondary machining required. However, the actual deposition efficiency, i.e., fraction of feedstock material that actually becomes part of the consolidated component, has been demonstrated to be as low as ~5%. In practice, the remainder of the powder is generally not reused, and becomes waste (waste powder), just like the machining chips. Consequently, these direct metal deposition processes also present critical issues in terms of sustainability. This research program has three primary research objectives: to formulate a quantitative assessment framework for environmental impact assessment and economic evaluation of direct metal deposition technologies, to utilize this framework to guide the experimental design space for utilizing waste powder and machining chips as alternative feedstock materials in direct metal deposition, and to implement the experimental design, including carefully controlled component fabrication, coupled with in-depth characterization and testing.

This research incorporates various assessment and evaluation tools into a quantitative assessment framework that captures the experimental variables associated with direct metal deposition, especially when utilizing alternative feedstock materials. This framework will be formulated so that it is integrated with and therefore guides the experimental design space, rather than being carried out after all the experimental parameters have been rigidly defined, as is the current norm for assessment studies. Overall, the research will advance the understanding of the performance-sustainability-economics trade-off space for direct metal deposition. Direct metal deposition is a relatively new technology that is promoted to be cost effective and sustainable, due to its ability to create parts through addition, rather than subtraction, of material. Yet the process currently has limitations in materials utilization, but moreover appears to be sufficiently robust to potentially overcome these limitations through the utilization of alternative feedstock materials. From a broad perspective, these topics present a foundational opportunity to highlight trade-offs between performance, sustainability and economics, and furthermore to promote the incorporation of sustainability and economic assessment early in the design process.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This NSF research program has established a quantitative assessment framework to assess the environmental impact and cost of directed laser deposition metal additive manufacturing technologies. This project provided insight into the fundamental relationships that link the feedstock powder, processing history, microstructure of the additively manufactured parts with mechanical behavior to guide the experimental design space for utilizing recycled waste powder, machining chips, and supporting structures as alternative feedstock materials, via carefully controlled component fabrication, coupled with in-depth characterization and testing.  The research has generated comprehensive information that is useful for sustainable material use in directed laser deposition.  For instance, one of the research efforts investigated how the energy consumption and cost of additive manufacturing can be reduced by using alternative feedstock rather than virgin gas atomized powder. This project identified an experimental strategy to treat recycled metal machining chips or waste supporting structures to convert them to powders suitable for additive manufacturing (See Images 1-2).  In addition, the mechanical properties of the parts made from the recycled machining chips or supporting structure waste are superior to those of the parts made from virgin gas atomized powder, such as higher local hardness (See Image 3). This research program also established a design space to achieve scalability of optimal thin wall processing parameters to deposit block samples under the same conditions, which showed equivalent to or better mechanical properties than cast materials (See Image 4). Furthermore, this project also demonstrated the feasibility to deposit ceramic particle reinforced aluminum alloy matrix composites (AMC) via directed laser deposition and elucidated the effect of processing parameters on the precipitate characteristics in the AMC (See Image 5). Lastly, this project provided a statistical analysis of powder flowability to guide the powder selection for improving the quality of parts fabricated with additive manufacturing. In summary, this research incorporated various assessment and evaluation tools into a quantitative assessment framework that captures the experimental variables associated with directed laser deposition, especially when utilizing alternative feedstock materials (See Image 6). This framework was integrated with the experimental design space, to further the feasibility of using alternative feedstock powders in metal additive manufacturing. Overall, the research advances the understanding of the performance-sustainability-economics trade-off space for metal additive manufacturing.

Through the performance period (07/01/2016 to 06/30/2020), this program has generated four journal papers, one conference proceedings paper, fifteen conference presentations, two master theses and one PhD dissertation. Two additional manuscripts are pending.

Broader Impacts:

The research program has generated fundamental knowledge that is beneficial to material processing, process design, mechanical engineering design, as well as industrial ecology, green engineering, life cycle assessment, techno-economic analysis and sustainable development of materials. The research activities have promoted intellectual collaborations and academic exchanges between University of California Irvine and Colorado State University. This collaborative program provided professional training of two M.S. graduate students, one Ph.D. student (female) and four undergraduate students (one female, one Hispanic), and promoted diversity in STEM education. These students participated in the analytical and laboratory activities, thereby expanding their skills and knowledge base in science, engineering, and technology.

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2020
Modified by: Julie M Schoenung

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit: This NSF research program has established a quantitative assessment framework to assess the environmental impact and cost of directed laser deposition metal additive manufacturing technologies. This project provided insight into the fundamental relationships that link the feedstock powder, processing history, microstructure of the additively manufactured parts with mechanical behavior to guide the experimental design space for utilizing recycled waste powder, machining chips, and supporting structures as alternative feedstock materials, via carefully controlled component fabrication, coupled with in-depth characterization and testing. The research has generated comprehensive information that is useful for sustainable material use in directed laser deposition. For instance, one of the research efforts investigated how the energy consumption and cost of additive manufacturing can be reduced by using alternative feedstock rather than virgin gas atomized powder. This project identified an experimental strategy to treat recycled metal machining chips or waste supporting structures to convert them to powders suitable for additive manufacturing (See Images 1-2). In addition, the mechanical properties of the parts made from the recycled machining chips or supporting structure waste are superior to those of the parts made from virgin gas atomized powder, such as higher local hardness (See Image 3). This research program also established a design space to achieve scalability of optimal thin wall processing parameters to deposit block samples under the same conditions, which showed equivalent to or better mechanical properties than cast materials (See Image 4). Furthermore, this project also demonstrated the feasibility to deposit ceramic particle reinforced aluminum alloy matrix composites (AMC) via directed laser deposition and elucidated the effect of processing parameters on the precipitate characteristics in the AMC (See Image 5). Lastly, this project provided a statistical analysis of powder flowability to guide the powder selection for improving the quality of parts fabricated with additive manufacturing. In summary, this research incorporated various assessment and evaluation tools into a quantitative assessment framework that captures the experimental variables associated with directed laser deposition, especially when utilizing alternative feedstock materials (See Image 6). This framework was integrated with the experimental design space, to further the feasibility of using alternative feedstock powders in metal additive manufacturing. Overall, the research advances the understanding of the performance-sustainability-economics trade-off space for metal additive manufacturing. Through the performance period (07/01/2016 to 06/30/2020), this program has generated four journal papers, one conference proceedings paper, fifteen conference presentations, two master theses and one PhD dissertation. Two additional manuscripts are pending. Broader Impacts: The research program has generated fundamental knowledge that is beneficial to material processing, process design, mechanical engineering design, as well as industrial ecology, green engineering, life cycle assessment, techno-economic analysis and sustainable development of materials. The research activities have promoted intellectual collaborations and academic exchanges between University of California Irvine and Colorado State University. These students participated in the analytical and laboratory activities, thereby expanding their skills and knowledge base in science, engineering, and technology.
